p:
The CUS surface climate biases in models have been documented in several previous studies
1 . In the historical simulations from 19 models participating in Phase 5 of the Coupled Model Intercomparison Project (CMIP5)
14 , the multi-model mean (MMM) biases of summertime temperature and precipitation over the CUS during the reference period 1979–2005 are up to 3° warmer (Fig. 1a), in which 14 out of 19 of the models agree on the sign of the warm bias, and up to 43% drier (Fig. 1b), in which 17 out of 19 of the models agree on the sign of the dry bias. The MMM warm and dry biases are present throughout the year, but they peak in the summer (Supplementary Table 1).
